content-ecr.removal-reaction-sub: Electro coagulation through the reaction chamber produces several distinct electrochemical results independently. These observed reactions could be explained as:

processes.title: Seeding
processes.description: Resulting from the anode reduction of metal ions that become new centres for larger, stable, insoluble complexes that precipitate as complex metal oxides.

processes.title: Emulsion breaking
processes.description: Resulting from the oxygen and hydrogen ions that bond into the water receptor sites of oil molecules creating a water insoluble complex separating water from oil, driller's mud, dyes, inks, etc.

processes.title: Halogen complexing
processes.description: As the metal ions bind themselves to chlorines in a chlorinated hydrocarbon molecule resulting in a large insoluble complex separating water from pesticides, herbicides, chlorinated PCB's etc.

processes.title: Bleaching
processes.description: by the oxygen ions produced in the reaction chamber oxidizes dyes, cyanides, bacteria, viruses, biohazards, etc.

processes.title: Oxidation - Reduction
processes.description: reactions are forced to their natural end point within the chamber, which speeds up the natural process of nature that occurs in wet chemistry.

processes.title: Electron flooding
processes.description: The water eliminates the polar effect of the water complex, allowing colloidal materials to precipitate, and the increase of electrons creates an osmotic pressure that ruptures bacteria, cysts, and viruses;

reactions.title: Main Reaction-1
reactions.content:
Main reactions at the electrodes are
Al → Al3+ (aq) + 3e (anode) 3H2O + 3e → 3/2H2 + 3OH− (cathode)

reactions.title: Main Reaction-2
reactions.content:
Meanwhile, if anode potential is sufficiently high, secondary reactions may occur also, such as direct oxidation of organic compounds and of Cl− ions present in wastewater
2Cl− → Cl2 + 2e

reactions.title: Main Reaction-3
reactions.content:
The chlorine produced is a strong oxidant that can oxidize same organic compounds and promote electrode reactions. In addition, the cathode may be chemically attacked by OH− ions generated during H2 evolution at high pH values:
2Al + 6H2O + 2OH− → 2Al (OH) 4− + 3H2

reactions.title: Main Reaction-4
reactions.content:
Generally, three main processes occur serially during electro coagulation:

  • Electrolytic reactions at electrode surfaces.
  • Formation of coagulants in aqueous phase.
  • Adsorption of soluble or colloidal pollutants on coagulants, and removal by sedimentation or floatation.
